facts.text: Consolidation proceedings under East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, 1948 were started in 1955 in village Bholpur of District Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1955, companysolidation proceedings under East Punjab Holdings  Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmenta- tion  Act, 1948  hereinafter called the Act  were started in the village Bholpur of District Ludhiana.

facts.text: Scheme for consolidation of holdings was published on 29th March, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the provisions of the Act, a scheme for companysolidation of holdings was published on 29th March, 1956.

facts.text: Scheme was confirmed under s. 20 of the Act on 14th May, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th May, 1956 that scheme was companyfirmed under s. 20 of the Act.

facts.text: Consolidation Officer re-allotted parcels of land to the appellant and respondents Nos. 1 and 8 in village Bholpur.

anchor.surface_text: The Consolidation Officer accordingly re-allotted parcels of land to the appellant and respondents Nos. 1 and 8 in the village of Bholpur.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 8 preferred appeals under s. 21(3) of the Act dissatisfied with the allotment.

anchor.surface_text: Being dissatisfied with the allotment, respondents 1 and 8 preferred appeals under s. 21 3  of the Act

facts.text: Appeals of respondents 1 and 8 under s. 21(3) were dismissed by the Settlement Officer.

anchor.surface_text: but these appeals were dismissed by the Settlement Officer.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 8 preferred further appeals under s. 21(4) to the Assistant Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 and 8 thereafter preferred further appeals under s. 21 4  of the Act to the Assistant Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

facts.text: Assistant Director partially allowed the appeal of respondent No. 1 by order dated 29th October, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Director partially allowed the appeal of respondent No. 1 by his order dated 29th October, 1957

facts.text: Assistant Director dismissed the appeal of respondent No. 8.

anchor.surface_text: but dismissed the appeal of respondent No. 8.

facts.text: Appellant moved the State Government under s. 42 of the Act on 10th February, 1958 for revision of the order passed by the Assistant Director in the appeal of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On 10th February, 1958, the appellant moved the State Government under s. 42 of the Act for revision of the order passed by the Assistant Director in the appeal of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Revision Petition was accepted on 29th August, 1958 by the Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

anchor.surface_text: The Revision Petition was ultimately accepted on 29th August, 1958 by the Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

facts.text: Director held that the original order by Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 was contrary to the scheme and based upon a mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The Director held that the original order made by the Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 was companytrary to the scheme and was based upon a mistake of fact.

facts.text: Harbhajan Singh filed two copies of the application under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Harbhajan Singh had filed two companyies of the application under s. 42 of the Act

facts.text: On one copy, Director passed order on 17th February, 1958 that the application should be put up with previous papers.

anchor.surface_text: and on one companyy the Director of Consolidation of Holdings passed an order on 17th February, 1958 that the application should be put up with previous papers.

facts.text: On the second copy, Director passed order on 3rd April, 1958: The order of Assistant Director need not be amended. File Inform.

anchor.surface_text: On the second companyy of the application the Director passed an order on 3rd April, 1958 to the following effect - The order of Assistant Director, Consolidation of Holdings, under s. 21 4  need number be amended. File Inform.

facts.text: On the copy with order of 17th February 1958, Director heard parties and passed order on 29th August 1958 allowing application of Harbhajan Singh and set aside order of Assistant Director.

anchor.surface_text: On the companyy of the application on which the order of 17th February, 1958 was passed, the Director heard the parties and passed his order on 29th August, 1958 by which he allowed the application of Harbhajan Singh and set aside the order of the Assistant Director.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 moved Punjab High Court under Art. 226 for quashing the order of Director dated 29th August 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 thereafter moved the Punjab High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, made on 29th August, 1958.

facts.text: Punjab High Court allowed the application on 11th January 1960 holding Director not competent to pass order dated 29th August 1958 in view of previous order dated 3rd April 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed by the High Court on 11 th January, 1960 on the ground that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, was number companypetent to pass the order dated 29th August, 1958 in view of his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh.

facts.text: Appellant took Letters Patent Appeal which was dismissed on 19th April 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter in appeal under Letters Patent but the appeal was dismissed on 19th April, 1960.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal brought by special leave from Punjab High Court judgment dated 19th April 1960.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ramaswami J.

under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, made on 29th August, 1958. anchor.surface_text: under s. 42 of the Act dated 29th August, 1958 is legally valid ? S. 42 of the Act states The State Government may at any time for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality or propriety of any order passed, scheme prepared or companyfirmed or repartition made by any officer under this Act call for and examine, the record of any case pending before or disposed of by such officer and may pass such order in reference thereto as it thinks fit Provided that numberorder, scheme or repartition shall be varied or reversed without giving the parties interested numberice to appear and opportunity to be heard except in cases where the State Government is satisfied that the proceedings have been vitiated by unlawful companysideration.

concepts.interpretation: Confers revisional jurisdiction on State Government to examine records and pass orders, but contains no express power of review over its own orders under this section

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: Singh under s. 42 of the Act. It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 42, East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, 1948
concepts.unlisted_description: Revisional powers of the State Government

anchor.surface_text: without giving the parties interested numberice to appear and opportunity to be heard except in cases where the State Government is satisfied that the proceedings have been vitiated by unlawful companysideration.

There is numberprovision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act. In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act. It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order by the grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: S. 76-A of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1958  Bombay Act LXVII of 1948  provides as follows Where numberappeal has been filed within the period provided for it, the Collector may, suo motu or on a reference made in this behalf by the Divisional Officer or the State Government at any time,-  a  call for the record of any enquiry or the proceedings of any Mamlatdar or Tribunal for the purpose of any order passed by, and as to the regularity of the proceedings of such Mamlatdar or Tribunal, as the case may be, and  b  pass such order thereon as he deems fit Provided that numbersuch record shall be called for after the expiry of one year from the date of such order and numberorder to such Mamlatdar or Tribunal shall be modified, annulled or reversed unless opportunity has been given to the interested parties to appear and be heard.

arguments.claim: There is no provision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act. In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director,

arguments.claim: In the absence of any such express power, the Director cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order by the grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: No court and no authority has a power of setting aside an order which has been properly made, unless it is given by statute

anchor.surface_text: In Drew v. Willis 1 , Lord Esher, M. R. pointed out that ,no court  and I would add no authority  has a power of setting aside an order which has been properly made, unless it is given by statute.

arguments.claim: The court under the statute has no power to review an order deliberately made after argument

anchor.surface_text: In another case Hession v. Jones 2  Bankes, J. pointed out that the court, under the statute, has no power to review an order deliberately made after argument and to entertain a fresh argument upon it

arguments.claim: The power to review must also be given by the statute

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was laid down by the Madras High Court in Anantharaju Shetty v. Appu Hegada 3  in which Seshagiri Aiyar, J. observed It is settled law that a case is no, open to appeal unless the statute gives such a right. The power to review must also be given by the statute.

arguments.claim: Commissioner had no power to review that order

anchor.surface_text: While dismissing the appeal of the defendant-appellant, Lord Atkinson said Their Lordships are clearly of opinion that the order of March 23, 1900, was final and conclusive, and that, so far as the Commissioner was concerned, he had no power to review that order in the way in which he has reviewed it.

arguments.claim: In the absence of any power of review the Collector had no power to reconsider his previous decisions and the subsequent order was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: In this state of facts, it was held by this Court that in the absence of any power of review the Collector had no power to reconsider his previous decisions dated October 3, October 4 and October 17, 1958 and the subsequent order of the Collector dated February 17, 1959 re-opening the matter was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: The Act does not empower the Collector to review an order passed by him under s. 76A

anchor.surface_text: These orders passed by the Collector in the exercise of his revisional powers were quasi-judicial, and were final. The Act does not empower the Collector to review an order passed by him under s. 76A.

arguments.claim: The same principle applies to the present case and the Director had no power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had no power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The subsequent order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 was ultra vires and illegal and was rightly quashed by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the subsequent order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings dated 29th August, 1958 allowing the application of Harbhajan Singh was ultra vires and illegal and was rightly quashed by the High Court.
